channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Surge in West Bank Violence Raises Further Concerns Among Israel’s Allies
item.description: The European Union and the United States have recently imposed new sanctions on settlers and groups that they say have incited violence against Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Israel in Talks Over Withdrawing From Egypt-Gaza Border, Officials Say
item.description: The discussions between Israeli and Egyptian officials comes amid diplomatic activity on several continents over a cease-fire deal and postwar plans for the territory.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Adam Rasgon, Vivian Wang and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A view of Rafah in the Gaza Strip, seen from the Egyptian side of the border, this month.

item.title: Masoud Pezeshkian Promises Change in Iran. Can He Deliver?
item.description: Masoud Pezeshkian, a widowed doctor, portrays himself as a reformer who can bring social and economic shifts. But others have tried and failed before him, and numerous obstacles are in his path.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masoud Pezeshkian at a rally in Tehran on the last day of campaigning before the election. He ended up winning in an upset.

item.title: Dysfunction Sidelines Ukraine’s Parliament as Governing Force
item.description: With the president’s party split, the government relies on formerly pro-Russian lawmakers to help it pass legislation and, the opposition says, minimize scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Independence Square in Kyiv. Ukraine’s Constitution assigns more power to the Parliament than the presidency. But the balance in wartime has been different.

item.title: Taiwan’s Blunt-Talking Leader Faces China’s Backlash
item.description: China is putting more military and political pressure on Taiwan and its new president, whose rhetoric has been sharper than his predecessor’s.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan has used direct language to reject China’s claim to the island. “According to international law, we are already a sovereign and independent country,” he told Time magazine.

item.title: Masha Gessen Sentenced in Absentia by Russian Court to 8 Years in Prison
item.description: Masha Gessen was found guilty of spreading “false information” and sentenced to eight years in prison over remarks made in 2022 about the Russian military.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Masha Gessen, shown in Germany last December, was found guilty of spreading “false information” about the Russian military by a court in Moscow.

item.title: North Korean Diplomat Defects to the South, Talks of Execution
item.description: Ri Il-kyu, who fled to South Korea late last year, alleged that two North Korean officials who had been assigned to negotiate with the Trump administration had been punished.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A file image of Ri Il Kyu, a senior North Korean diplomat who defected to the South last November, was aired on news program in the South on Tuesday.

item.title: Heavy Downpours and Flooding Kill Dozens Across South Asia
item.description: Climate change has created more intense monsoon seasons in the region, displacing millions and gutting buildings, bridges and villages.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Flooding in Assam, India, earlier this month.

item.title: Gareth Southgate Resigns as England Coach
item.description: Despite losing the final of Euro 2024 to Spain, Southgate’s eight years in charge lifted his country’s men’s team back into the top tier of international soccer.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Initially hired as a temporary manager, Gareth Southgate became the longest-serving manager of the England’s men’s team in more than three decades.

item.title: Vaughan Gething, First Minister of Wales, Resigns
item.description: Vaughan Gething became the first minister of the Welsh Parliament in March. But a growing controversy over campaign financing precipitated his decision to step down.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Vaughan Gething in Cardiff in March, when he became the first Black person to lead a national government in Europe.

item.title: Kenyan Police Arrest Suspected Serial Killer of 42 Women
item.description: The police said that nine mutilated and dismembered bodies had been discovered, and that the suspect had confessed, only the latest violence against women in a rising tide of it in the East African nation.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Rescuers carry sacks with human remains after being removed from a quarry in Mukuru Kwa Njenga area in Nairobi, Kenya, on Saturday.

item.title: The Book Bag That Binds Japanese Society
item.description: No rule requires Japan’s elementary school students to wear the boxy, bulky backpack known as the randoseru. But for nearly 150 years, nearly all of them have.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Noriko Hayashi
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nearly every elementary school student in Japan carries a book bag known as a randoseru, a staple of Japanese childhood for close to 150 years.

item.title: Ukraine Battles to Contain Russian Advances Across the Front
item.description: Russian forces appear to have captured Urozhaine, a southern village taken back by Ukraine last summer. In the east, they are closing in on a key supply road.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A soldier from an artillery unit of Ukraine’s 95th Separate Air Assault Brigade preparing to fire at Russian troops trying to capture the city of Toretsk, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Gambia Votes to Keep Ban on Female Genital Cutting, in Dramatic Reversal
item.description: Lawmakers in the West African country had supported overturning the prohibition, but changed course on Monday after a vociferous campaign led by women.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Gambian National Assembly members voted to continue the ban on female genital mutilation on Monday.

item.title: I.M.F. Sees Signs of Cooling in U.S. Economy
item.description: The International Monetary Fund warned that inflation remained stubbornly high and that protectionism posed a risk to the global economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: A line for a South Florida job fair. “The United States shows increasing signs of cooling, especially in the labor market, after a strong 2023,” wrote Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas, the I.M.F.’s chief economist.

item.title: J.D. Vance’s Chance
item.description: Why Donald Trump tapped Vance to be his successor.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator J.D. Vance and his wife, Usha, at the convention last night.

item.title: What Trump 2.0 Could Mean for the Environment
item.description: If Donald Trump returns to the White House, he would likely face fewer legal and bureaucratic obstacles to dramatically remake the E.P.A.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.category: Chevron v Natural Resources Defense Council (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former president Trump has promised to repeal federal regulations designed to cut greenhouse gases.

item.title: NASA Sends a Missy Elliott Song to Space
item.description: NASA sent the song “The Rain (Supa Dupa Fly)” from a radio dish in California last week. It took 14 minutes to travel the 158 million miles.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Missy Elliott performing at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles last year.

item.title: J.D. Vance’s Opposition to U.S. Support for Ukraine: In His Own Words
item.description: “I don’t really care what happens to Ukraine one way or the other,” Senator Vance has said.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: J.D. Vance has been one of Congress’s most vocal opponents of U.S. aid for Ukraine.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Running Mate
item.description: Plus, a judge dismisses a criminal case against Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance, once a critic of Donald Trump, is now his running mate.

item.title: South Korea Bans Everything Bagel Seasoning
item.description: The seasoning is sold by Trader Joe’s, a brand whose popularity has skyrocketed in the region in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson

item.title: J.D. Vance Is an Oil Booster and Doubter of Human-Caused Climate Change
item.description: He once said society had a climate problem but changed his position sharply while seeking Donald Trump’s endorsement in his Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Vance has accused the Biden administration of “wanton harassment of fossil fuel companies.”

item.title: Spanish Police Find Body Where British Teenager Jay Slater Disappeared
item.description: Jay Slater disappeared on the Spanish island of Tenerife last month. A missing persons group said Monday that a body had been found with his possessions.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: The Masca ravine on Tenerife, where Jay Slater went missing in June.

item.title: Pakistan Says It Will Ban Party of Jailed Former Leader Imran Khan
item.description: The move was widely seen as the latest effort by a weak governing coalition to squash Mr. Khan’s political popularity.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Supporters of Imran Khan, the former prime minister of Pakistan, celebrating after a court verdict overturned his illegal marriage conviction, in the capital, Islamabad, on Saturday.

item.title: China Will Host Senior Officials of Hamas and Fatah, Longtime Adversaries
item.description: A rapprochement between the rival Palestinian factions could make postwar governance of Gaza more feasible.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Hassan Ammar/Associated Press
item.media:description: Fatah’s delegation will include Mahmoud al-Aloul, left, the deputy chairman of the party. Ismail Haniyeh, the political leader of Hamas, will lead Hamas’s delegation.

item.title: Bodies in Suitcases Prompt 2-Day Manhunt and Murder Arrest in U.K.
item.description: A grisly discovery last week in Bristol, England, led the police to a 34-year-old man who had stayed with the victims in London.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Investigators at a home in London, where two murder victims had lived.

item.title: The R.N.C. Begins
item.description: The latest on the assassination attempt and presidential campaign — plus, an explanation of why childbirth has gotten so expensive.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Law enforcement outside the arena that will host the Republican National Convention.

item.title: What’s Greenest and Cleanest When Nature Calls?
item.description: Conventional toilet paper has a big environmental impact. We’ve got the lowdown on alternatives, from bamboo tissue to bidets.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Anne Brown

item.title: Each Year Flying Ants Emerge Across the U.K. And Yes, They’re Annoying.
item.description: Winged ants emerge from the soil on hot summer days with one goal: find a mate — fast. These insects are annoying, but experts say they play a vital role in the environment.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Flying ants erupting from the ground to start their nuptial flight, in Kettlestone, England, on Aug. 23, 2016.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: After shots rang out, Donald Trump was swarmed by Secret Service agents.

item.title: They Were Told They Were in a Safe Area. Then Came the Missiles.
item.description: Survivors of a strike in Gaza on Saturday that Israel said had targeted Hamas’s top military leader described a scene of carnage, with fire, smoke, blood and bodies everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: Gaza health officials said that more than 90 people were killed in the strike on Saturday and more than 300 injured.

item.title: With Rivals Restricted, Kagame Looks Set for Another Term in Rwanda
item.description: The Central African nation is voting on a potential fourth term for President Paul Kagame. Opposition figures say they have been threatened and arbitrarily detained.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Guillem Sartorio for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Paul Kagame of Rwanda greeting supporters at a campaign rally in the capital, Kigali, on Friday. Mr. Kagame, 66, is widely expected to win a fourth term.

item.title: Euro 2024 Final: Spain Beats England to Claim Fourth Title
item.description: A 2-1 victory in the Euro 2024 final extended England’s suffering but crowned a generational star in Spain’s teenage forward, Lamine Yamal.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Spain’s European Championship was its fourth, a record for the competition.

item.title: Israel Struck Twice in Its Attack on Al-Mawasi, Videos and Photos Show
item.description: Visual evidence from Saturday’s strike in Gaza that left dozens dead appears to show that the Israeli military launched a separate strike near emergency vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen

item.title: Monday Briefing: An Assassination Attempt on Donald Trump
item.description: Plus, a major Israeli airstrike in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: After shots rang out, Donald Trump was swarmed by Secret Service agents.

item.title: Israel’s Attempted Assassination of Hamas Leader Followed Surveillance of Deputy
item.description: Israel officials had been hoping that a high-ranking Hamas figure, Muhammad Deif, would visit a villa tied to a top lieutenant. They struck when he appeared to be there, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: The strike, which the Israeli military says targeted a Hamas leader, took place in an area designated as a humanitarian zone.

item.title: Olympic Torch Reaches Paris in Elegant Style
item.description: The flame has been on a long journey since its arrival in May, but hopes that it would bring the country together have foundered on political division.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Thierry Henry, left, a soccer legend in France, next to the Olympic torch that he would soon carry through the streets of Paris on Sunday. At right are Tony Estanguet, a top Olympics official, and Anne Hidalgo, the mayor of Paris.

item.title: Nepal’s New Prime Minister Is Named After Government Collapses
item.description: K.P. Sharma Oli, who leads the nation’s largest communist party, is to take office on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: The veteran politician K.P. Sharma Oli, center, at Parliament in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Friday.

item.title: Kate, Princess of Wales, Plans to Attend Wimbledon Final
item.description: The princess has stepped back from the public eye since her cancer diagnosis earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club
item.media:description: Catherine, Princess of Wales, presented the winning trophy to Carlos Alcaraz of Spain, who won the men’s singles final on Sunday at the Wimbledon tennis championship.

item.title: From Exile in London, a Crime Novelist Works to Transform Russia
item.description: Boris Akunin, the creator of a hugely popular detective series, hopes that fomenting a vibrant Russian culture abroad might undermine President Vladimir V. Putin’s government at home.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boris Akunin left Russia in 2014 to protest his country’s illegal annexation of Crimea. He has lived in Britain ever since.

item.title: Are Games Like the Euro 2024 Final the Riskiest Gig in Music?
item.description: Performing before a major match like the Euro 2024 final offers priceless visibility, and the nonzero chance that you’ll be booed.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Lenny Kravitz performed shortened versions of three songs in a six-minute set before the Champions League final in June.

item.title: In England, a Changed Nation Hopes for a Change in Soccer Fortunes
item.description: After installing a Labour government for the first time in 14 years, the country is looking to a historical precedent as a presage to a long-awaited sporting success.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: England flags in London. As the country prepares to play Spain in the European final in Berlin on Sunday, there’s a sense of a nation turning the page, on the field and off.

item.title: Israel Launches Major Attack Against a Senior Hamas Commander
item.description: The target, Muhammad Deif, was an architect of the Oct. 7 attacks and has been the object of repeated Israeli assassination attempts over decades.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A Palestinian man carrying the body of his son, who was killed in an Israeli strike in the Mawasi area of Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Acquittal for Pakistan’s Khan and Wife in Illegal Marriage Case
item.description: But Imran Khan, the popular former prime minister, remains incarcerated for now, and the authorities have indicated that new charges are likely.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan and his wife, Bushra Bibi, in court last year.

item.title: Who Is the Hamas Military Leader, Muhammad Deif?
item.description: Muhammad Deif, an architect of Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack and commander of the group’s military wing, was the focus of an Israeli strike on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: An undated handout photo said to be Muhammad Deif, the Hamas military leader.

item.title: Over 100 United Nations member states pledge support for UNRWA, and other news.
Slowing Down Like Scarlett
item.description: Take a cue from a movie star: Simplify your life this weekend.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times

item.title: Can Canada Trim Its Reliance on Foreign Labor?
item.description: For the first time, the government will set a cap on visas for temporary residents, including temporary workers and students, this fall.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Fabrizio Costantini for The New York Times
item.media:description: Agriculture in Canada has long relied on temporary foreign workers.

item.title: Ukraine Is Targeting Crimea, a Critical Base for Russia’s Invasion
item.description: Newly armed with deep-strike missiles, Kyiv is trying to degrade Russian abilities on the peninsula, aiming at airfields, air defenses and logistics hubs.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A woman paying tribute to those who died when debris from an intercepted Ukrainian missile fell on a beach last month near the Crimean city of Sevastopol.

item.title: How Janet Yellen Became an Unlikely Culinary Diplomat
item.description: The Treasury secretary views food as a way to connect, and her dining decisions have become the subject of global intrigue.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen prizes mixing in cultural experiences with the grind of government travel.

item.title: How Hamas Is Fighting in Gaza: Tunnels, Traps and Ambushes
item.description: Hamas overwhelmed Israel’s border in October with a coordinated, large-scale maneuver before committing atrocities. Now, it acts as a guerrilla force, its fighters often disguised as civilians.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Natan Odenheimer, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Sella and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers, photographed during a tour organized by the Israeli military, standing near the entrance to what the military said was a Hamas tunnel, near the Erez border crossing in Gaza, in December.

item.title: Colombia Faces a New Problem: Too Much Cocaine
item.description: Even as production surges, domestic and foreign shifts in the global drug industry have devastated many poor Colombians whose livelihoods are tied to cocaine.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roger Guzman, 19 years old, working harvesting coca leaves. December 2023 in, Colombia.

item.title: Big Indian Weddings Highlight Economic Divide
item.description: Henna artists’ elaborate designs are a hallmark of Indian weddings. They also highlight a disparity where some are fabulously rich and many earn very little.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Elke Scholiers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mehndi artists applying their trade at the Bangalore Club, in Bengaluru, India, in July. Applying the elaborate henna designs is time-consuming, and often it is used as the excuse for a party among the overall wedding festivities.

item.title: This Soccer Player Wanted to Wear Her Hijab on the Field. France Wouldn’t Let Her.
item.description: Lina Boussaha joined a team in Saudi Arabia so she could wear her head scarf while playing the sport she calls “a part of my soul.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes and Iman Al-Dabbagh
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lina Boussaha practicing in her new home, Khobar, Saudi Arabia, in March.

item.title: Where Germany’s Immigration Debate Hits Home
item.description: Since the recent killing of a police officer, Mannheim has become the byword for a hard line on deporting those who are denied asylum and commit violent crime.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Frank-Walter Steinmeier of Germany paying tribute in June to Rouven Laur, a police officer who died after a knife attack in Mannheim.

item.title: Gaza City Neighborhood Left in Ruins After Israeli Troops Withdraw
item.description: Intense fighting between soldiers and Hamas militants has left parts of the city uninhabitable, say residents who returned.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek, Julian E. Barnes, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in the Shajaiye neighborhood east of Gaza City on Thursday after the Israeli military withdrew following a two-week offensive.

item.title: Hamas Official: ‘We’re Not Obstinate’ in Cease-Fire Talks on Gaza
item.description: Husam Badran said the militant group would give up civilian control in the territory, but would not disband its military wing.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Husam Badran, a senior Hamas official, in Doha, Qatar, this week. He said Hamas was willing to cede civilian control in Gaza to nail down a postwar deal, but not to disband its military wing.

item.title: How Ukraine’s ‘Irreversible’ Path to NATO May Hinge on U.S. Election
item.description: Hanging over the alliance’s summit in Washington this week was the shadow of the U.S. presidential election, which added a layer of unpredictability to the war and to the future of the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: President Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine during the NATO summit in Washington, on Thursday.

item.title: Early Wildfires in Brazil Threaten Pantanal Wetlands and Cerrado Savanna
item.description: Huge blazes are spreading hundreds of miles across some of the most biodiverse parts of Brazil, with the worst of the annual fire season still weeks away.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: A fire burning in late June along the banks of the Paraguay River in the Pantanal, the world’s largest tropical wetlands, where fires this year have burned an area about the size of Phoenix.

item.title: France Is at a Political Impasse Ahead of 2024 Olympics
item.description: After elections produced a deadlocked Parliament, both left and right are claiming victory, while President Emmanuel Macron insists no one won. It’s a recipe for turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Statues of the “Marianne,” the French Republic’s iconic national figure, in front of the National Assembly building in Paris, in honor of the upcoming Olympics.

item.title: Nepal’s Prime Minister Dahal Loses Confidence Vote in Parliament
item.description: The latest political upheaval comes as Nepal struggles to cope with deadly disasters like a landslide on Friday that left more than 60 people missing.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal of Nepal arriving to speak before Parliament in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Friday.

item.title: Pakistan Court Grants Imran Khan’s Party More Seats in Parliament
item.description: A ruling by Pakistan’s top court strips the governing coalition of its two-thirds majority, and thrusts the party of Imran Khan back onto the political main stage.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Supporters of former prime minister Imran Khan celebrate after a Supreme Court verdict, in Karachi, Pakistan, on Friday.
